Statistical Principle

Statistical Principle.Rmd

We here illustrate the statistical principle of TGVIS for fixed per-SNP heritability and inflation factor. The model we consider is ğ³=nğ‘ğÌ‚ğ›‰+nğ‘ğ›„+ğ›œ, \boldsymbol z=\sqrt{n}\mathbf R\hat{\mathbf B}\boldsymbol\theta+\sqrt{n}\mathbf R\boldsymbol\gamma+\boldsymbol\epsilon, where ğ³\boldsymbol z is the vector of z-scores of outcome GWAS at the target locus, nn is the sample size of outcome GWAS, ğ‘\mathbf R is the LD matrix, ğÌ‚\hat{\mathbf B} is the matrix of direct xQTL effects of gene-tissue pairs, ğ›‰\boldsymbol\theta is the vector of causal effects of gene-tissue pairs, ğ›„\boldsymbol\gamma is the vector of direct causal effects of variants, and ğ›œ\boldsymbol\epsilon is the residual of this model. Under the model setting of TGVIS, ğ›œ=nğ‘ğ›–+ğ‘12ğ›†, \boldsymbol\epsilon=\sqrt n\mathbf R\boldsymbol\upsilon+\mathbf R^{\frac12}\boldsymbol\varepsilon, where ğ›–\boldsymbol\upsilon is a vector of infinitesimal effects, and ğ›†\boldsymbol\varepsilon is a vector of independent and identically distributed (IID) normal variables.

We previously assumed that ğ›–âˆ¼ğ’©(0,ÏƒÏ…2ğˆ)\boldsymbol\upsilon\sim\mathcal N(0,\sigma_\upsilon^2\mathbf I) and ğ›†âˆ¼ğ’©(0,ğˆ)\boldsymbol\varepsilon\sim\mathcal N(0,\mathbf I), and estimate the variance ÏƒÏ…2\sigma_\upsilon^2 via REML. However, Dr.Â Can Yangâ€™s group have proposed multiple works, including MR-APSS and XMAP, which all assume:

  • The variance ÏƒÏ…2\sigma_\upsilon^2 can be used as the per-SNP heritability estimated by LDSC,

  • The variance of ğ›†\boldsymbol\varepsilon should be the intercept of the LDSC which is usually larger than 1.

Therefore, we added the parameter estimate_inf in TGVIS. When estimate_inf=T, it executes the original TGVIS, while when estimate_inf=F, users need to provide two parameters: var_inf and residual_variance, which are the per-SNP heritability and intercept estimate in LDSC, respectively.

When fixing ÏƒÏ…2\sigma_\upsilon^2 to be per-SNP heritability, we can analytically obtain the conditional distribution of ğ³\boldsymbol z: ğ³âˆ¼ğ’©(nğ‘ğÌ‚ğ›‰+nğ‘ğ›„,aÌ‚ğ‘+nÏƒÌ‚Ï…2ğ‘2), \boldsymbol z\sim\mathcal N(\sqrt{n}\mathbf R\hat{\mathbf B}\boldsymbol\theta+\sqrt{n}\mathbf R\boldsymbol\gamma,\hat a\mathbf R+n\hat \sigma_\upsilon^2\mathbf R^2), where aÌ‚\hat a is the intercept estimate in LDSC and ÏƒÌ‚Ï…2=hÌ‚2/M\hat \sigma_\upsilon^2=\hat h^2/M is the per-SNP heritability, hÌ‚2\hat h^2 is the heritability estimate and MM is the number of total variants. The weighted least square (WLS) corresponding to this conditional distribution is: ğ’¬(ğ›‰,ğ›„)=(ğ³âˆ’nğ‘(ğÌ‚ğ›‰+ğ›„))âŠ¤ğ›€(ğ³âˆ’nğ‘(ğÌ‚ğ›‰+ğ›„)), \mathcal Q(\boldsymbol\theta,\boldsymbol\gamma)=(\boldsymbol z-\sqrt{n}\mathbf R(\hat{\mathbf B}\boldsymbol\theta+\boldsymbol\gamma))^\top\mathbf\Omega(\boldsymbol z-\sqrt{n}\mathbf R(\hat{\mathbf B}\boldsymbol\theta+\boldsymbol\gamma)), where ğ›€\mathbf\Omega is the inverse of aÌ‚ğ‘+nÏƒÌ‚Ï…2ğ‘2\hat a\mathbf R+n\hat \sigma_\upsilon^2\mathbf R^2.

Note that for non-clumping data, the number of SNPs is in the range 3000-10000, depending on how large the locus is. In this case, the LD matrix ğ‘\mathbf R is not positive definite: it has a large number of zero eigenvalues. Hence, we slightly modified the TGVIS function to make it robust to this high-dimensional setting. Specifically, we added the parameter eigen_thres with a default value of eigen_thres=0.999. We calculate the cumulative proportion of variance explained by the eigenvalues of ğ‘\mathbf R, and find K such that the cumulative proportion exceeds eigen_thres. Then the inverse matrix ğ›€\mathbf\Omega is approximated by ğ›€K=âˆ‘k=1K(1dkaÌ‚+ndk2ÏƒÌ‚Ï…2)ğ”kğ”kâŠ¤, \mathbf\Omega_{K}=\sum_{k=1}^K\bigg(\frac{1}{d_k\hat a}+\frac{n}{d_k^2\hat\sigma^2_\upsilon}\bigg)\boldsymbol U_k\boldsymbol U_k^\top, where ğ”1,â€¦,ğ”K\boldsymbol U_1,\dots,\boldsymbol U_K are the first KK eigenvectors of ğ‘\mathbf R and d1,â€¦,dKd_1,\dots,d_K are the first KK eigenvalues of ğ‘\mathbf R.

The next step is straightforward: we first yield the inner product matrix: ğšº=(ğ‘ğÌ‚,ğ‘)âŠ¤ğ›€K(ğ‘ğÌ‚,ğ‘),ğƒ=diag(ğšº), \mathbf\Sigma=(\mathbf R\hat{\mathbf B},\mathbf R)^\top\mathbf\Omega_{K}(\mathbf R\hat{\mathbf B},\mathbf R),\quad \mathbf D=\sqrt{\text{diag}(\mathbf\Sigma)}, and then calculate R and z: R=diag(ğƒ)âˆ’1ğšºdiag(ğƒ)âˆ’1,z=diag(ğƒ)âˆ’1(ğ‘ğÌ‚,ğ‘)âŠ¤ğ›€Kğ³. \text{R}=\text{diag}(\mathbf D)^{-1}\mathbf\Sigma\text{diag}(\mathbf D)^{-1},\quad \text{z}=\text{diag}(\mathbf D)^{-1}(\mathbf R\hat{\mathbf B},\mathbf R)^\top\mathbf\Omega_{K}\boldsymbol z. Note that R and z are the notations of parameters in susie_rss().
